TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}

S.TRANSL: We remember you with affection, teacher.

S.FORM: małimałi aravats a kinuletj sun nua tja Tsemas i vavaw sa su pasamaza i Tayuangi, sa su sikanemanga tua nia kai a katsalisian, sana ne kemłang anga.
maljimalji aravac a kinoletj son noa tja Cemas i vavaw sa so pasamaza i Tayoangi, sa so sikanemanga toa nia kai a kacalisian, sana ne kemljang anga.
S.TRANSL: Thank you very much that our God provided you and you were sent here to Taiwan, and you dealt with (?) the language of us people of the mountain slopes and we were able to understand.

S.FORM: pai aitsu a mareka katsalisian nisun a tami.
pai aico a mareka kacalisian nison a tami.
S.TRANSL: And so the mountain people are your people.

S.FORM: pai kana ika sun a namangtjez qau kana men a kemłang tua nia vetsik a kinatsalisianan.
pai kana ika son a namangtjez qao kana men a kemljang toa nia vecik a kinacalisianan.
S.TRANSL: If you had not come how could (?) we have known the writing for our mountain language?
We are extremely glad about it.

S.FORM: saka pai aitsu nu vaik sun uta uła men a su sikainulinuli, uła men a temudutudur sakamaya tua nia sinku a mareka su kaka imaza i katsalisian, sana ne kana inulinuli uta tjanusun.
saka pai aico no vaik son ota olja men a so sikainolinoli, olja men a temodotodor sakamaya toa nia sinko a mareka so kaka imaza i kacalisian, sana ne kana inolinoli ota tjanoson.
S.TRANSL: And now when you go may you pray for us, so that we your brothers and sisters here in the mountains may continue always in our faith and pray too for you.

S.FORM: nu vaik anga sun nu i djalan anga sun, uła sun a napupitsupitsul anga uta; nu i djalan anga sun, uła sun a namalevalevanga a mangtjez itua mareka su matjałałak a mareka su kaka.
no vaik anga son no i djalan anga son, olja son a napopicopicol anga ota; no i djalan anga son, olja son a namalevalevanga a mangtjez itoa mareka so matjaljaljak a mareka so kaka.
S.TRANSL: When you go and are on your journey may you be in good health; and on your way may you be glad to reach your parents and brothers and sisters.

S.FORM: saka pai aitsu a tiamen a uri su vinaikan uła men a su kinipaqenetjan sa su kainulinulian amen, uła men a napasusu tua tulu nua Tsemas tua kai nua tja kaka ti Yisu-sama, uła tjen a namakaya metsevutsevung i tjarivavaw, nu namakapasusu itjen tua tulu nua tja Tsemas i vavaw.

saka pai aico a tiamen a ori so vinaikan olja men a so kinipaqenetjan sa so kainolinolian amen, olja men a napasoso toa tolo noa Cemas toa kai noa tja kaka ti Yiso-sama, olja tjen a namakaya mecevocevong i tjarivavaw, no namakapasoso itjen toa tolo noa tja Cemas i vavaw.
S.TRANSL: And we whom you are leaving behind may you remember us and pray for us, so that we will keep the teaching of God and the words of our brother Jesus; may we be able to meet up above if we have fully kept the teaching of our God above.
That’s all I have to say.
